slides.title: EcAZ Phage Project Progress
slides.subtitle: Group Meeting Report
slides.notes:
Good morning/afternoon, everyone!

Today I'll be presenting the latest progress on our EcAZ phage project. The goal of this project is to isolate bacteriophages that can infect EcAZ E. coli strains from sewage samples, laying the foundation for future phage therapy research.

I'll cover the project background, isolation results, host range determination, and our ongoing titer determination experiments.

slides.title: Project Background
content: Objective: Isolate phages infecting EcAZ E. coli from sewage
slides.notes:
Let me start with the project background.

Our core objective is to isolate bacteriophages capable of infecting EcAZ E. coli from sewage samples. Why sewage? Because it's a natural reservoir of phage diversity, containing a rich variety of bacteriophages.

We used two host strains for screening: EcAZ-1, a wild-type strain we call W, and EcAZ-2-OVA, an engineered strain expressing the OVA antigen, which we call R.

The ultimate application of this project is phage therapy research.

slides.title: Phage Isolation Results
slides.notes:
Through multiple rounds of enrichment and purification, we successfully isolated five bacteriophages.

R1, R2, and R3 were enriched using the R strain, while W1 and W2 were enriched using the W strain.

Notably, these five phages exhibit distinct plaque morphologies. R1 produces tiny plaques, R2 produces turbid plaques—suggesting it might be a temperate phage. R3 produces large, clear plaques with high titer.

Each phage underwent 4-6 rounds of purification to ensure pure isolates.

slides.title: Plaque Morphology Characteristics
slides.footnote: ⭐ R2 is the only turbid plaque (possibly temperate); R3 has the largest plaques
slides.notes:
Now let's examine the plaque morphology in detail.

We characterized three parameters: diameter, clarity, and halo presence.

For diameter, R1 is the smallest at 0.1-0.2mm, while R3 is the largest at 3.2mm—a 15-fold difference!

Regarding clarity, four phages produce clear plaques, but R2 is uniquely turbid. Turbid plaques typically indicate temperate phages capable of lysogenic cycles.

For halos, all except R2 show prominent halo zones, suggesting these phages may carry polysaccharide-degrading enzymes.

slides.title: Host Range Determination Results
slides.notes:
Now let's look at the host range determination results—this is where we made a very important discovery!

Please pay attention to the R1 row. It can only infect the R strain and completely fails to infect the W strain. This is the only narrow-host-range phage among all five isolates!

Why can R1 only infect the R strain? One possible explanation is that the OVA protein expressed on the R strain's surface creates a unique receptor that R1 specifically recognizes.

The other four phages all have broad host ranges and can infect both strains.

slides.title: Titer Determination Progress
slides.notes:
Currently, the titer determination experiment is in progress.

On January 14th, we completed strain activation. On January 15th, we performed streak plating and picked single colonies. Today, January 16th, we completed the double-layer agar plating.

Since R3 showed very high titers in previous experiments, we used a higher dilution range from 10^-8 to 10^-14.

We expect to observe results tomorrow.

slides.title: Conclusions & Future Plans
findings: R1 is the only **narrow-host-range** phage, infecting only EcAZ-2-OVA
R2 produces **turbid plaques**, possibly temperate phage
R3 has the **largest plaques** (3.2mm) and highest titer
slides.notes:
Let me summarize our main findings and future plans.

Four key findings: First, we successfully isolated five bacteriophages. Second, R1 is the only narrow-host-range phage—a valuable discovery. Third, R2 produces turbid plaques, suggesting temperate phage behavior. Fourth, R3 has the largest plaques and highest titer.

Next steps: Complete titer determination this week, then conduct one-step growth curve experiments and proceed to DNA extraction and genome sequencing.

Thank you all for your attention!

If you have any questions or suggestions, I'd be happy to discuss them. I'm particularly interested in hearing your thoughts about R1's narrow host range mechanism and R2's turbid plaque nature.

Thank you!
